metadata.title: Chirality, a neglected physico-chemical property of nanomaterials? A mini-review on the occurrence and importance of chirality on their toxicity

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Toxicology Letters
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/toxlet
Mini review
Chirality, a neglected physico-chemical property of nanomaterials? A minireview on the occurrence and importance of chirality on their toxicity
Wells Utembe

sections.heading: Toxicology and Biochemistry, National Institute for Occupational Health, South Africa
sections.text: A R T I C L E I N F O

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Chirality Nanoparticles Nanotoxicology Surface chemistry Biocompatibility Enantiomers
A B S T R A C T
Toxicity assessments are required for nanomaterials which are being used in many fields such as medicines, electronics, pesticides, clothes and construction materials. One factor that usually affects toxicity of chemicals is chirality. This paper reviews the existence of chirality in nanoparticles and critically analyses the implications of chirality on toxicological risk assessment of nanoparticles. Chirality and optical activity arise from lack of symmetry, where an object is non-superimposable on its mirror image. Optical isomers or enantiomers have similar physico-chemical properties but only differ in their optical activity and their interaction with biological systems. Chirality is not limited to organic molecules, but also exists in inorganic compounds and crystals. Studies have also shown that chirality can be bestowed onto nanoparticles by adsorption of chiral molecules, and by careful design of the crystal to expose chiral kinked and stepped surface structures. Just as chirality has been shown to affect the biological activities of conventional chemicals, nanoparticles functionalised with different enantiomers have been shown to exhibit enantioselectivity and different toxicities. However, at the moment more studies on the ligands and the conditions under which chirality occurs in NPs, as well as on the effects of NP chirality on protein adsorption kinetics and thermodynamics. Nevertheless, this cursory analysis has shown the importance of chirality on biological activity of nanoparticles. In cases where there is a potential for the existence of chirality in nanomaterials (either intrinsic or extrinsic), there may be need for adequate consideration of the effects of chirality.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nanomaterials (NMs) are defined as materials that have structural components smaller than 100 nm (nm) in at least one dimension (Buzea et al., 2007). Relatedly, particles that are smaller than 100 nm are referred to as nanoparticles (NPs). Much research is conducted on NMs because of their unique chemical, physical, electrical, and mechanical properties, attributes that have many applications in medicines, electronics, food, pesticides, textiles, construction materials and many others. Despite the great prospects offered by NMs, there are safety concerns mainly regarding worker, consumer and environmental safety that may be caused by manufacturing and use of NMs, as well as the disposal of NM waste. Therefore, assessment of the toxicity of NMs is warranted before their wide application.
The toxicity of NMs is affected by many factors, including size, material composition, shape, functional groups, zeta potential, surface area, and concentration (Buzea et al., 2007). However, the effect of chirality, which is well recognized in conventional chemicals, has not been well studied. Chirality is a phenomenon where an object contains an asymmetric point, with the result that there can be two non-
superimposable mirror images in three-dimensional space as shown in Fig. 1 below. For molecules, the asymmetric point is often a carbon atom with four different functional groups.
Chirality is not only limited to molecules but has also been shown to exist in crystals and NPs, as long as there exist non-superimposable images arising from an asymmetric point (Gautier and Bürgi, 2009; Gautier and Bürgi, 2008; Oila and Koskinen, 2006). This paper gives an overview on chirality, assesses the existence of chirality in NMs, and critically analyses the implications of chirality on the toxicology and risk assessment of NMs.

sections.heading: 2. The nature and importance of chirality in biochemical sciences
sections.text:
Chirality was first observed in cut crystals, where different crystals rotated the plane of polarized light either to the left or to the right. Similar effects were observed in natural organic products, such as sugars, turpentine oil, camphor, and tartaric acid (Smith, 2009). Chiral substances exist as pairs of enantiomers. Enantiomers, which rotate the plane of polarized light either left or right, are said to be optically active or optical isomers. Optical isomers have identical molecular formulae

and connectivity of atoms, but different arrangement of atoms in space. Optical isomers belong to a wider group of stereoisomers, which include all isomers that differ only in the orientation of the atoms in space. Stereoisomers also include geometric (cis/trans) isomers and diastereoisomers, which are molecules with more than one chiral centre, resulting in non-mirror images of one another (Smith, 2009).
The lack of symmetry of non-superimposable objects is more easily understood by the concept of handedness, where chiral objects are classified as either being left-handed or right handed. However, it is important to understand that although all handed objects are chiral, not all chiral objects are handed. In other words, there are objects and molecules that may exhibit non-handed chirality (King, 2003).
Enantiomers have identical physical and chemical properties, but show differences in their optical activity or their effect on polarised light. In other words, they have the same melting points, boiling points, chemical reactivity and other physicochemical properties but they rotate the plane of polarised light in opposite directions. The enantiomer that causes rotation to the right is said to be dextro-rotary (+) or d-, while the other that causes rotation to the left, levo-rotary (−) or l-. Other naming conventions for chiral substances also exist involving the use of D/L (Fischer projections) as well as R (for rectus), or S (for sinister) (Cahn-Ingold-Prelog System) (Smith, 2009). An equal mixture of two enantiomers is called a racemic mixture, and is optically inactive.
As a consequence of their interaction with polarised light, chiral molecules exhibit what is referred to as circular dichroism (CD). CD occurs at wavelengths of light where different enantiomers absorb polarised light to different extents. For this reason, polarimetry and CD are among chiroptical methods, i.e. methods that can differentiate between two enantiomers. Other methods used in analysis of chiral substances include nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), mass spectrometry (MS), Xray crystallography and chiral chromatographic methods (Okuom et al., 2015; Purdie and Swallows, 1989).
Chirality is not limited to organic molecules, as it also exists in inorganic compounds, especially in coordination metal complexes (King, 2001), where it arises from the spatial arrangement of ligands around the central ion (King, 2001; von Zelewsky, 1996), as illustrated in Figs. 2 and 3.
As chirality can exist at all length scales (Gellman, 2010) and is not limited to molecules and complexes, it is also possible for geometric objects and surfaces to exhibit intrinsically chiral structures (Gautier and Bürgi, 2009). A geometrical object is chiral or dissymmetric if its mirror image cannot be brought to coincide with itself (Li et al., 2011). As it was discussed in the introduction section, chirality was first noted in cut crystals. A crystal is said to be ‘chiral if the spatial arrangement of its atoms is not superimposable with its mirror image’ (Dryzun et al., 2009). Chiral compounds produce optically active crystals upon crystallisation (Walkiewicz, 2011), and there are many chiral crystals in nature, with quartz being the most common. The chirality in quartz arises from the helical arrangement of SiO4 tetrahedra in the bulk structure (Horvath and Gellman, 2003; Sholl and Gellman, 2009). Therefore, it is possible to collect enantiomerically pure quartz crystals by selecting the correct crystals based on the orientation of the crystal faces (Sholl et al., 2001).
Living systems are chiral entities, and many molecules in nature possess particular enantiomeric configurations. For example, the amino acids in human beings are primarily L-amino acids, while carbohydrates in human beings are D-carbohydrates (Smith, 2009). Therefore, as a result, most physiological processes involve very precise molecular interactions, where chiral receptor molecules can distinguish two enantiomeric substrate molecules (Noyori, 2002). In such chiral environments, enantiomers are likely to experience selective biochemical interactions including absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination (ADME). Consequently, each enantiomer can have different pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, therapeutic and toxicological profiles (Smith, 2009).
The importance of chirality has been well recognised in conventional chemicals, especially in the areas of medicinal drugs and pesticides. For example in the area of medicine, the S enantiomer and not the R enantiomer of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug Dexketoprofen inhibits cyclooxygenase activity (Hutt and Valentova, 2003). For these reasons, drugs ‘usually require specialized chiral techniques for their correct identification, characterization, separation and measurement’(USFDA, 1992). Consequently, the United States Food and Drug administration (USFDA) issued a guidance policy on the
study and pharmaceutical development of chiral drugs (USFDA, 1992). Furthermore, the role of chirality on the effects of drugs is so vital that many drugs that were developed as racemates have undergone chiral switches to improve their therapeutic and toxicological profiles (Agranat et al., 2002; Hutt and Valentova, 2003).
In environmental management, chirality has also been known to affect many important environmental parameters, such as degradation rates, bioaccumulation, persistence, and toxicity (Wong, 2006; Ye et al., 2010, 2015). As an example, the effects and the environmental fate of the enantiomers of chiral pesticides can be significantly different, to the extent that the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA), requires among other things, studies of biotic processes for each enantiomer as well as toxicity data for enantiomerically-enriched or non-racemic mixtures of pesticides (USEPA, 2000). Therefore, as chirality affects many pharmacological and toxicological profiles of many conventional chemicals, they are likely to affect the pharmacological and toxicological profiles of NMs. Therefore, the occurrence and importance of chirality in NMs are discussed in the next few sections.

sections.heading: 3.1. Occurrence and applications of chirality of nanoparticles
sections.text:
Chirality has been extensively studied and reported with regard to organic molecules and inorganic complexes. However, there is relatively less literature on chiral (crystalline) surfaces, and there is even less literature on chirality in NMs. Despite the apparent little interest, chiral surfaces play important roles in the chemical interactions that occur at solid/liquid interfaces. These interactions are important in many processes including catalysis and weathering as well as the design and the development of many products such as chemical sensors, medicines, pesticides, paints, glues and solvents (Hazen and Sholl, 2003).
Chirality can be induced on particles in two ways. First of all, chirality can be bestowed onto achiral particles (i.e. particles with no optical activity) by adsorption of chiral molecules (Govorov et al., 2011; Kumar et al., 2016; Shemer et al., 2006). In this case, the transfer of chirality from the adsorbing molecules to the particle surface largely depends on the structure of the adsorbing molecules. A schematic illustration of a NP core surrounded by chiral adsorbing molecules is shown in Fig. 4 below.
As an example of chirality bestowed on NPs by a chiral adsorbate, optically active thiols (D- or L-cysteine) were used to modify surfaces of chemically synthesized 5 nm gold (Au) NPs to render them chiral (Shukla et al., 2010). Existence of chirality in both the D- or L-cysteinecapped Au NPs was confirmed by CD spectroscopy. Furthermore, the Lcysteine –capped Au NPs could selectively adsorb the (R)-propylene oxide while D-cysteine-capped Au NPs could adsorb S-propylene.
Optical activity was also confirmed in D- and L-penicillamine-capped 1–2 nm Au nanoclusters (Au NCs) (Yao et al., 2005), while there were no CD signals when the Au NCs were synthesized using racemic penicillamine. Chiral 2 nm Au NPs were also prepared using other thiol ligands such as N-isobutyryl-cysteine (Gautier and Bürgi, 2006) and 1,1'- binaphthyl-2,2'-dithiol (Gautier et al., 2008) while chiral 65 nm gold nanoflowers were prepared using guanosine 5'-monophosphate (5’- GMP) and L-ascorbic acid (L-AA) (Huang et al., 2012). It has been demonstrated that exchange of a chiral thiol with its opposite enantiomer reverses the optical activity, although the form of the CD spectra is unaffected (Gautier and Bürgi, 2008). Other examples of chirality in Au NPs are discussed elsewhere (Gautier and Bürgi, 2009).
Chirality has also been reported in originally achiral 4.4 nm cadmium selenide (CdSe) quantum dots (QD) using chiral thiol ligands (Land D-cysteines) (Tohgha et al., 2013a, b). Opposite CD signals were observed for the CdSe QDs capped with D- and L-cysteine and, most remarkably, the CD spectra could only be observed after replacing some achiral trioctylphosphine oxide/oleic acid ligands on the achiral nanocrystals with the chiral D- and L-cysteines.
Chirality was also observed in 2 nm and 5 nm silver (Ag) NPs synthesized in deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) (Molotsky et al., 2010; Shemer et al., 2006), 5–20 nm AgNPs synthesized in mucin glycoprotein (Hendler et al., 2011), as well as 23.5 nm Ag NPs functionalised with cysteine, glutathione (GSH) and penicillamine (Li et al., 2004). Ag NCs (< 2 nm) with prominent optical properties were also prepared using several optically active thiols, including captopril ((2S)-1-[(2S)-2-methyl-3-sulfanylpropanoyl]pyrrolidine-2-carboxylic acid), GSH, and cysteine (Cathcart et al., 2009), as well as L and D penicillamine (Nishida et al., 2008).
In addition to Au NPs, Ag NPs and QDs, chirality has also been reported in other NPs including>300 nm silica NPs (Li et al., 2016a) as well as in 30–50 nm TiO2 NPs aggregates of 3–4 nm nanorods (Cleary et al., 2017). The mechanistic origins of optical activity of functionalized NPs are beyond the scope of this paper, but are presented elsewhere in the literature (Guerrero-Martínez et al., 2011; Hidalgo and Noguez, 2016; Noguez and Garzón, 2009; Sánchez-Castillo et al., 2010).
Many ligands are often used to improve specific properties of NPs (Mout et al., 2012; Ross and Roeder, 2011; Subbiah et al., 2010). Some of these ligands possess a centre of asymmetry, such as an asymmetric carbon atom, as shown in Table 1. The ability to cause this effect appears to depend on a number of factors including the ability to undergo self-assembly mediated by hydrogen bonds, the ability to interact with the cluster surface through at least two functional groups, and distance of the chiral center from the NP surface (Gautier and Bürgi, 2009). As the occurrence of chirality in NPs may be relatively prevalent, more studies on the ligands and the conditions under which chirality occurs in NPs are warranted.
In addition to chirality conferred on NPs by chiral adsorbates, chirality in NPs can be intrinsically induced by careful design of crystals to expose “chiral kinked and stepped surface structures” (McFadden et al., 1996). This type of chirality that occurs in crystals at the nanoscale is similar to the chirality in macroscopic and microscopic crystals that results from the geometry of the crystals. The kink sites lack symmetry, are ‘either left- or right-handed, and can be thought of as chiral, when the step lengths on either side of the kink site are unequal’ (McFadden et al., 1996). In this manner, it is possible to prepare single NP crystal surfaces with intrinsic handedness (Raval, 2003). As
an example, pure quartz crystals can be prepared with intrinsic chirality arising from the helical arrangement of silica tetrahedral (Soai et al., 1999).
Intrinsic chirality has also been reported in Au NCs (Dolamic et al., 2015; Knoppe and Bürgi, 2014), as well as in carbon nanotubes (CNTs) (Imtani and Jindal, 2009; Liu et al., 2011), fullerenes (Maroto et al., 2014) and silicon nanotubes (Wang et al., 2017a). Among Au NCs, intrinsic chirality has been reported in thiolate ligand (SR) protected crystal structures such as Au102(SR)44, Au38(SR)24, and Au28(SR)20 (Dolamic et al., 2012; Knoppe and Bürgi, 2013; Knoppe and Bürgi, 2014; Lopez-Acevedo et al., 2010), as well as in tris(2-(diphenylphophino)ethyl)phosphine) (PP) protected Au20(PP3)4]Cl4 (Knoppe et al., 2014). The chirality, which is reportedly strong, is said to arise from inherent chirality of the cluster core, arrangement of achiral ligands on the surface of the cluster, or cis/trans isomerism in the bridged Au–S binding motifs. However, as synthesis of these NCs yields racemic mixtures, separation of enantiomers is required (Knoppe and Bürgi, 2014).
As cylindrical structures composed of carbon atoms in rolled-up graphene sheets, the intrinsic chirality of CNTs arises from the manner the graphene layer is folded, as defined by a pair of integer indices (n, m) that denote the chiral angle θ (the degree of degree of helicity of the lattice) and the chiral vector (the roll-up direction) (Pérez and Martín, 2012; Rao and Govindaraj, 2011). Chirality in CNTs has only been rarely demonstrated practically because of challenges in enantiomeric separation of CNTs (Dukovic et al., 2006; Wei et al., 2016). Nevertheless, CD spectra of CNTs have been demonstrated theoretically (Sato et al., 2017; Yokoyama et al., 2014). Similarly, intrinsic chirality of fullerenes, which result from an asymmetric arrangement of carbon atoms and addends around the cages (Maroto et al., 2014), has been both experimentally and theoretically in many fullerenes (Hirsch et al., 1994; Wilson et al., 1996; Yang et al., 2011).
It is important to note that chirality transfer does not only occur from chiral ligands to achiral NPs but also in the reverse direction. Through the use of vibrational circular dichroism (VCD), chirality transfer was observed to occur from an intrinsically chiral Au NCs to an achiral adsorbate (Dolamic et al., 2015). In this study, solutions of chiral Au38 clusters capped with 2-phenylethylthiolate demonstrated strong VCD signals in vibrations of the achiral adsorbate. Furthermore, two mirror images could be identified. In addition, there can also be enhancement of CD signals by non-chiral metal NPs to the chiral molecules, as well as inducement of new CD signals in the plasmon region (Abdulrahman et al., 2012; Govorov et al., 2010; Lieberman et al., 2008). This chirality originates from Coulomb interactions between a chiral molecule and the NP (Govorov et al., 2010). Excitation of surface plasmons at surfaces of NPs does not only result in the enhancement of CD signals in molecules adjacent to the surfaces of the nanoparticles but also enhancement of several other optical phenomena such as surfaceenhanced fluorescence, surface-enhanced Raman scattering and surface-enhanced infrared absorption (Lieberman et al., 2008).
The CD and optical rotatory dispersion effects in chiral NMs can be many times larger than those observed in ordinary chiral molecules (Smith et al., 2017), and chiral solid surfaces can differentiate between enantiomers of a chiral species in the same manner as chiral molecules (Sholl et al., 2001). For example, powdered enantiomerically pure quartz crystals were used in the asymmetric synthesis of chiral pyrimidyl alkanols (Soai et al., 1999). However, preparation of intrinsically chiral NPs is more challenging than addition of a chiral adsorbate to a metal surface to create a chiral metal surface (Mallat et al., 2007). For example, since synthesis of CNTs results in a mixture of CNTs of different chirality, preparation of CNTs with a distinct chirality or isolation of CNTs from a batch based on their chirality is reportedly very difficult (Skandani et al., 2012; Zhang and Zheng, 2010). Nevertheless, whether dealing with intrinsic or extrinsic chirality, the whole area of chiral nanotechnology, (i.e. nanotechnology that makes use of chirality), offers vast opportunities in materials and biochemical
sciences, including the manufacture of chiroptical molecular devices (molecular switches and motors), development of enantioselective catalysts, as well as in DNA nanotechnology (Bag et al., 2008; Bönnemann and Braun, 1997; Zhang et al., 2005).

sections.heading: 3.2. Interactions of chiral nanoparticles with biochemical systems and implications for toxicological risk assessment
sections.text:
Similar to chirality in organic molecules, chirality has been shown to affect the interactions of chiral surfaces with biological systems. For example, surface chirality was shown to significantly influence the adsorption of blood plasma protein (bovine serum albumin and fibrinogen) on TiO2 films functionalised with L and D lysine as well as L and D tartaric acid (Fan et al., 2017). In this regard, proteins had a stronger interaction with chiral centres on L-Lysine than those on DLysine, resulting in more proteins adsorption on L-Lysine. On the other hand, there was more protein adsorption on D- tartaric acid as compared to L- tartaric acid. In a similar manner, chirality has been observed to influence adsorption of proteins in NPs. For example, chirality of the surface of 14 nm gold (Au) NPs arising from functionalization with D, L or racemic penicillamine was shown to determine the orientation and conformation of transferrin which, in turn, affected the interaction and recognition of transferrin with its receptor on the cellular membrane (Wang et al., 2017b). Similarly, cell adhesion to Janus enantiomorphous NM assembly structures was shown to be chiralitydependent, especially in serum-containing media (Kehr, 2017; Motealleh et al., 2018). These studies have shown the enantioselective adsorption of NMs to biomolecules, including proteins. However, a mechanistic understanding of the effects of chirality on protein adsorption kinetics and thermodynamics (isotherms) is required.
The enantioselective biomolecule adsorption may have many significant consequences. Firstly, adsorption of NPs to cells is an important step that can determine the amount of internalized NPs (Cho et al., 2009; Wilhelm et al., 2003). The adsorption is followed by the interaction of the NP with components of the cell membrane such as proteins, polysaccharides, lipids, and other components. With the exception of glycine, the amino acids in the proteins and the sugars in polysaccharides are chiral. Consequently, cell uptake by NPs is expected to be affected by chirality through enantio-selective adsorption of NPs to cells as well as enantio-selective interaction of adsorbed NPs with cell components. Indeed, chirality has been shown to affect the in vitro uptake of 16 nm Au NPs modified with 2-mercaptoacetyl-valine (MAV) and poly(acryloyl-valine) (PAV) of different chirality (Deng et al., 2016). While there were no differences in the uptake of the L- and DMAV-Au NPs by A549 cells and HepG2 cells, there were chirality-dependent differences in the uptake of PAV-Au NPs, with significantly greater internationalization for D-PAV-Au NPs than for L-PAV-Au NPs. The differences in cellular uptake was attributed to the enantio-selective interaction of L-phospholipid-based vesicles in the cell membrane with the D-PAV molecules.
Enantioselective rates of uptake were also observed in 1 nm CNTs, where CNTs with lower chiral indices (lower chirality) were shown to penetrate lipid bilayer cell membranes faster than those with higher chirality (Skandani et al., 2012). In this regard, CNTs with lower chirality required shorter times to translocate through the membrane because of their weaker adhesion to the membrane. Chiral indices were utilised in this study because of the much harder challenge of synthesizing CNTs with a distinct chirality. An evidently enantio-selective process was also observed for CdSe/ZnS QDs, where the cellular uptake of L-Cysteine QDs was almost twice as effective as that of D-Cysteine QDs (Martynenko et al., 2016).
These studies have shown that chirality can affect uptake of NPs. However, not much is currently known on the effects of NP surface chirality on cellular uptake and the resultant biological effects. Chirality may not only result in different NP uptake rates but may also affect intracellular distribution of NPs. For example, an analysis by
Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) indicated that more D-PAVAu NPs (16 nm) were located in the cytoplasm and closer to the cell nuclei of A549 cells than L-PAV-Au NPs, while almost all the L-PAV-Au NPs were located in lysosomes. Furthermore, L-PAV-Au NPs and DPAV-Au NPs were mainly distributed in lysosomes of HepG2 cells regardless of chirality (Deng et al., 2016).
The enantio-selective adsorption, uptake and intracellular distribution discussed in the previous paragraphs are by themselves expected to affect toxicities of chiral NPs, through their direct effect on biodistribution of NPs. Furthermore, chirality may affect toxicity of NPs through different surface chemistry and surface reactivity (Fu et al., 2014) as well enantio-selective corona formation (Kehr and Jose, 2017; Tenzer et al., 2013). Indeed, it was shown that the chirality of GHS surface coating could affect the cytotoxicity of 3.2 and 4.2 nm QDs in human hepatoma HepG2 cells (Li et al., 2011). In addition, cadmium telluride (CdTe) QDs coated with either the D enantiomer of GSH (DGSH) or the L enantiomer (L-GSH) showed a dose-dependent and a chirality-dependent cytotoxicity, with L-GSH-QDs being more toxic than D-GSH-QDs (Li et al., 2011).
The chirality-dependent toxicity modification by GSH was also shown in 4 nm Au NCs using human gastric cancer MGC-803, human gastric epithelial GES-1, and human breast adenocarcinoma MCF-7 cell lines (Zhang et al., 2015). Both L-GSH coated and D-GSH coated Au NCs generated reactive oxygen species (ROS) and exhibited cell physiologyrelated cytotoxicity effects such as mitochondrial depolarization, DNA damage, cell cycle arrest and apoptosis mediated death. However, DGSH coated Au NCs were comparatively more toxic than L-GSH coated Au NCs in both MGC-803 and GES-1 cells based on ROS induction. Furthermore, while both L-GSH coated Au NCs and D-GSH coated Au NCs caused the global up-regulation of genes involved in cellular rescue and stress response, only D-GSH coated Au NCs induced the most statistically significant changes (up-regulation) in metabolic pathways, steroid biosynthesis, metabolism of xenobiotics by cytochrome P450, as well as Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptors (PPAR) signaling pathway. The chirality-dependent ability of chiral GSH coated 4–5 nm Au NCs to regulate genes was also demonstrated in a separate study where non-cytotoxic levels of L-GSH coated Au NCs could down-regulate the mRNA expression levels of ten-eleven translocation (TET) 1 and 2 (Ma et al., 2016).
Furthermore, graphene quantum dot (GQDs) functionalized with chiral biomolecule D-glutamic acid (D-Glu) were shown to possess effective antimicrobial activity and high selective toxicity against microorganisms in mammalian cells, while its enantiomer displayed negligible antimicrobial activity (Xin et al., 2017). In addition, greater selective autophagy could be induced in cells and tissues by self-assembled chiral nano-device modified with D-GSH as compared to the LGSH-modified assembly (Sun et al., 2018). Similarly, only AuNPs coated with the D-enantiomer of poly (acryloyl-valine) (PAV) could induce selective autophagy and a high tumor eradication efficiency in breast cancer cells (Yuan et al., 2018).
Chirality has already been observed to affect the toxicity of nanomedicines. For example, chiral penicillamine-capped D-Pen@Se NPs, which can act as amyloid-β (Aβ) inhibitors in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease, were shown to have less in vivo toxicity than LPen@Se NPs (Sun et al., 2017). Less cytotoxicity and enhanced cellular uptake in human breast cancer cells (MCF-7) were also reported for doxorubicin hydrochloride (DOX) loaded on 100 nm mesoporous silica NPs which were rendered chiral by addition of 3-N-aminopropyl-L-tartaric acid triethoxysilane (APTTES) (Li et al., 2016b).
All of these examples demonstrate the potential impact that chirality may have on the toxicity of NMs. Therefore, results of toxicity studies could depend on whether the D or L enantiomer (or even the racemate) was used in the study. This notwithstanding, although chirality has been shown to be an important determinant or mediator of toxicity and other biological phenomena in some NPs, there are cases where chirality of NPs has no discernible effect, depending on the
nature of the ligands and nature of NPs. For example, 10–20 nm CdSpenicillamine tetrapods elicited little cytotoxicity in the NG108-15 neuroblastoma cells, regardless of chirality (Govan et al., 2010). Similarly, chirality did not influence the free radical scavenging capability of CNTs (Galano, 2009). Therefore, the effects of chirality need to be studied on a case-by-case basis, as necessary, most especially because optical activity of NPs appears to be size- and shape-dependent (Tohgha et al., 2013a; Xia et al., 2011).
It is also important to note that chirality may not affect toxicity of NPs by direct interaction of NPs with biological systems only, but also indirectly by modifying exposure parameters such as rates of aggregation, which are influenced by the relative interplay between attractive van der Waals forces and repulsive electrostatic interactions. For example, chirality has been shown to affect ‘aggregation kinetics of 117 and 208 nm Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes’ (SWCNTs) (Khan et al., 2013). In this case, the effect of chirality on SWCNTs could be attributed to the higher van der Waals interactions in the armchair SWCNTs, which resulted in substantially enhanced aggregation. By affecting the aggregation kinetics, chirality can significantly affect the delivered dose of NMs, which is partly responsible for inconsistencies among results from many in vitro studies (Cohen et al., 2015). Indeed, agglomeration and aggregation has been shown to have significant effects on cell uptake and toxicity of Au NPs (Albanese and Chan, 2011) as well as on the correlation between the dose of CNTs and nanofibres and their toxicological outcomes (Murray et al., 2012). Therefore, it may be important to assess the effects of chirality on dosimetry in these systems.
This paper has shown that the chirality of NPs can influence the biological properties of NPs, including their uptake, distribution and subsequently toxicity. Therefore, although most nanotoxicological research is conducted on achiral NPs, it is very important to be cognizant of its occurrence and presence, as well as to assess and report the possible implications on relevant toxicological results. Otherwise, inadequate consideration of the effects of chirality on toxicity and environmental behaviour may result in conflicting, irreproducible as well as misleading results. Since chirality may determine toxicity and environmental behaviour, chirality should be included, whenever relevant, among the physico-chemical properties conducted for NMs. Relatedly, manufacturers of NPs that are used in toxicological and biochemical research are urged to report the chirality of the NPs, whenever applicable. Secondly, as two enantiomers of the same NMs may exhibit different toxicities as well as environmental behaviour, it is important to design studies that can detect any chirality-dependent toxicological effects and environmental behaviours. Such studies need necessarily to be conducted on the racemate and the two enantiomers separately, as well as on any relevant enantiomeric ratios of the NMs.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: As most physiological processes depend on very precise molecular interactions involving receptor and substrates, chirality can play an important role in biological activities of NMs. Chirality can be bestowed onto NMs by adsorption of chiral molecules and by careful cutting of crystals to expose chiral kinked and stepped surface structures. Both forms of chirality would result in enantioselectivity of the NMs, with subsequent differential effects on toxicity and environmental fate. This paper, therefore, recommends more studies on the ligands and the conditions under which chirality occurs in NPs, as well as on the effects of NP chirality on protein adsorption kinetics and thermodynamics (isotherms). In cases where there is a potential for the existence of chirality in nanomaterials (either intrinsic or extrinsic), there may be need for adequate consideration of the effects of chirality.

As chirality can exist at all length scales (Gellman, 2010) and is not limited to molecules and complexes, it is also possible for geometric objects and surfaces to exhibit intrinsically chiral structures (Gautier and Bürgi, 2009).
A geometrical object is chiral or dissymmetric if its mirror image cannot be brought to coincide with itself (Li et al., 2011).
A crystal is said to be ‘chiral if the spatial arrangement of its atoms is not superimposable with its mirror image’ (Dryzun et al., 2009).
Chiral compounds produce optically active crystals upon crystallisation (Walkiewicz, 2011), and there are many chiral crystals in nature, with quartz being the most common.
The chirality in quartz arises from the helical arrangement of SiO4 tetrahedra in the bulk structure (Horvath and Gellman, 2003; Sholl and Gellman, 2009).

metadata.abstractText: Toxicity assessments are required for nanomaterials which are being used in many fields such as medicines, electronics, pesticides, clothes and construction materials. One factor that usually affects toxicity of chemicals is chirality. This paper reviews the existence of chirality in nanoparticles and critically analyses the implications of chirality on toxicological risk assessment of nanoparticles. Chirality and optical activity arise from lack of symmetry, where an object is non-superimposable on its mirror image. Optical isomers or enantiomers have similar physico-chemical properties but only differ in their optical activity and their interaction with biological systems. Chirality is not limited to organic molecules, but also exists in inorganic compounds and crystals. Studies have also shown that chirality can be bestowed onto nanoparticles by adsorption of chiral molecules, and by careful design of the crystal to expose chiral kinked and stepped surface structures. Just as chirality has been shown to affect the biological activities of conventional chemicals, nanoparticles functionalised with different enantiomers have been shown to exhibit enantioselectivity and different toxicities. However, at the moment more studies on the ligands and the conditions under which chirality occurs in NPs, as well as on the effects of NP chirality on protein adsorption kinetics and thermodynamics. Nevertheless, this cursory analysis has shown the importance of chirality on biological activity of nanoparticles. In cases where there is a potential for the existence of chirality in nanomaterials (either intrinsic or extrinsic), there may be need for adequate consideration of the effects of chirality.
